Entries.default: A round-bellied man stands at ease before a cluster of hardened fighters, their fists balled and brows furrowed.
"What are you needing from me?" Apāro offers a friendly nod.
"Farewell."
"Let him pass! Ruāsare gets the final word."
Entries.female: "Let her pass! Ruāsare gets the final word."

Entries.default: "We are no better than the outsiders if our Mataru act like inhospitable savages!"
"If you have such love for outsiders, let this one speak for himself!" She fixes her attention on you.
Entries.female: "If you have such love for outsiders, let this one speak for herself!" She fixes her attention on you.

Entries.default: "Give me a chance to prove myself worthy of your hospitality."
"I'm not here for a fight. It would be a mistake to start one."
"If you fight me, you will all die."
[Attack] "There's only one inhospitable savage on this plateau, and he stands before you."
Entries.female: [Attack] "There's only one inhospitable savage on this plateau, and she stands before you."

Entries.default: [Attack] "I already don't like where this is going, so let's skip to the good part."
"Ask me if I am tired of being wrong, Apāro." Grimacing, the warriors attack.
"Maybe the spear's a gift for us?"
"At least now we have the measure of you." Displeased by the confirmation, she gestures for her warriors to stand down.
"I'm a Watcher. The gods brought me here."
"There! Would you deny Burapo his first favorable omen of the season?" A smile slowly spreads across Apāro's cheeks. He passes you a knowing glance.

"If the outsider turns on us, I say I will drag you through Tangaloa's maw with me."

She curls her upper lip at Apāro.
"You are not the first to speak in honeyed words while caressing a hidden blade."
She grimaces at you, but her spear wavers.
"I take it you and Ruāsare are paired?"
"When it strikes Ruāsare's fancy that we should sleep under one roof, we do so vigorously."
"Some think I influence her judgment, but they have the wrong of it."
"Are you and Ruāsare married?"
Apāro regards you with confusion, and then bursts into laughter.
"How the outsiders enjoy their vows! The Huana pair off, but we need no documents or witnesses."
"Ekera, I doubt he even knows the meaning of the word." Tekēhu slaps his hand over his eyes, grinning with embarrassment.
"I'm familiar with the foreign obsession with vows." He favors you with a friendly smile.
"The outsider must leave. Ori o Koīki will not be parceled off and bought with foreign lies." She sweeps her speartip to gesture in your direction.
"I take it there's a problem."
"You are the problem. We do not track dirt in our home."
"Silence!" She grimaces at Edér.
[Back away slowly.]
"Not another step, or I kill you where you stand!"
"Ruāsare would never let that happen! Where is your confidence in our ranga?"
"For all our sakes, may I be proven wrong." Nodding to the assembled fighters, she signals them to disperse.
"I just got here. You haven't even given me a chance to cause trouble."
"Ekera, and you will not have a chance."
"Why are the Wahaki so protective of their land?"
"We safeguard any land that the trading companies have not stolen out from under Onekaza's throne."
"The islands will fall if the tribes do not recall our past and Ngati's covenant."
"Why so much concern over the past?"
"Back to my other questions."
"Ask. I am pleased to be making a new friend."
"We lost much of ourselves when cataclysm scoured the Deadfire."
"Ekera, my apologies, but I should say no more."
"There is Ukaizo, a place where the Huana can find themselves again."
"Somewhere among the islands, there's a place where we..." He stops himself and bites his lower lip.
"What are your thoughts on Ukaizo?"
"Ukaizo is out there. I am knowing this in my heart." He nods slowly, staring off into the distance.
"I cannot speak of lost Ukaizo to an outsider. That is not our way."
"It is the resting place of dead kings, their tombs engraved with our forgotten histories."
"Ukaizo is home. Our destiny is to return."
"Is there usually much infighting when outsiders show up?"
"Outsiders come with cannons, nets, torches. They do not come to talk."
"Where is the courtesy and welcome of the Wahaki?" His questions casts a ripple of unease over every listener.
"On behalf of those of us who remember our manners, welcome to Ori o Koīki." He sighs and shakes his head at the warriors before refocusing on you.
"What can you tell me about Ruāsare?"
"She is our ranga and the strength of our tribe." He stands tall, wearing a proud grin.
"I have never seen her without a mouthful of koīki. Even in battle she wears a bandoleer of fruit."
"A spirited, passionate, and very hungry woman is my Ruāsare."
"Ekera. I say circumstances have made us... rough around the edges."
Murmurs of tense discussion slow to a halt as a woman at the head of the crowd steps forward clutching a spear.
"Ruāsare mentioned that your sister is trapped on Crookspur."
"Do you seek Bauha and her captors, then? May Amira give you swift winds."
"Bauha could rip the big toe from Eothas' adra foot, but I would see her returned."
"She once threw a knobshell crab at the back of my head after I teasingly called her a coward."
"May my sister's passage through the jaws of Tangaloa go smoothly." Apāro squeezes his eyes shut and shakes his head.
"My sister returns grinning with accomplishment, and speaking your name! Well done, outsider." Apāro claps you on the arm and nods.
"Only the handsome fish can stay." She waves her spearpoint toward Tekēhu.
He swallows and raises his palm in mute greeting.
"I travel with Ngati's chosen. He will keep me honest."
"I will? I mean... ekera, I will." Tekēhu bows his head and touches his forehead.
"I wear the mark with... not pride." He rubs the back of his head self-consciously, shrugging.
"Ngati's covenant?"
"Ngati bade her followers to protect the islands, the tribes, and the luminous adra."
"For this she gave us the power to shape her domain. If we fail in our charges, the birthright of the Huana disappears."
"The Wahaki remember this. The Kahanga... they forget."
When he turns to face Tekēhu, Apāro's joyful face creases with worry.
"Some of us remember. What we choose to do with the memory is ours to decide." Tekēhu glances away.
"The covenant to protect the islands, the tribes, and the luminous adra?"
"Ekera, just so."
"My back is too fragile for the weight of authority, I say."
"Outsiders, here? For Ruāsare!"
